title: Product-Specific GenAI Needs to Write for the Web
description: Generative-AI outputs need to be concise, scannable, follow the inverted pyramid, and use plain language.
author: Taylor Dykes
excerpt: Generative-AI outputs need to be concise, scannable, follow the inverted pyramid, and use plain language.
text: Summary:¬† Generative-AI outputs need to be concise, scannable, follow the inverted pyramid, and use plain language. Users don‚Äôt read ‚Äî they scan. To accommodate this behavior, content writers use techniques like chunking, bullet points, and strategic formatting to improve scannability. Unfortunately, many product teams have forgotten these principles in their rush to include generative AI (genAI) tools. Our recent study showed that AI-generated content often violates fundamental principles of writing for the web. Emulate Broad-Scope AI Tools Concision Formatting for Scannability Inverted Pyramid Approachable¬†Language Learning About the User We recently ran a study looking at how people use various product-embedded genAI features like Carvana‚Äôs Sebastian or Instagram‚Äôs AI search and how these tools compare with broad-scope, general-purpose AI tools like ChatGPT and Perplexity. Overall, we found that, although not perfect, broad-scope AI chat tools produce outputs that are more scannable and easier to read than narrow-scope, product-embedded AI tools. While AI teams might not have control over the outputs generated by an LLM, it is worth exploring options for finetuning outputs and following best practices for web writing. This issue may be eventually addressed as these product-specific AIs integrate broad AI models that already adhere to the principles of writing for the web. However, users may not have the patience to wait until then. ChatGPT is a gold standard for content design in genAI. Its formatting and structure all aid the user‚Äôs comprehension. Concision Here at NN/g, we follow the slogan "Brevity = Brilliance."¬†Shorter text increases user comprehension and engagement. Users read only about 20% of written content on any given web page, so it‚Äôs doubly important that those words count. Generative AI outputs often end up being unnecessarily long. Take a look at this output to the question What are pet-friendly rug materials? from Rufus, Amazon‚Äôs generative AI. Compare it to the much shorter human-revised version. üö´ AI-Generated: Too Wordy ‚úÖ Human-Revised: Concise When choosing a pet-friendly rug material, consider the following options: Wool - Wool is a popular choice for pet owners as it is durable, naturally stain-resistant, and easy to clean. Its dense fibers can withstand heavy traffic and accidental spills. Synthetic Fibers - Synthetic rugs made of nylon, polyester, or polypropylene are also pet-friendly. They are resistant to stains, moisture, and wear, making them ideal for high-traffic areas. Sisal And Jute - These natural fibers are durable and pet-friendly, but they are not as stain-resistant as wool or synthetic materials. They are best suited for low-traffic areas or areas where pets are less likely to have accidents. Leather - Leather rugs are durable and easy to clean, making them a good choice for pet owners. They are resistant to stains and odors, and their smooth surface makes it difficult for pets to scratch or damage them. A TLDR or whatever‚Äù While summaries could increase users‚Äô ability to consume the content, they might not be necessary if the information was formatted for scannability. Formatting for Scannability Another guideline for writing for the web is to use scanning-friendly formatting choices that break up text and direct attention to the most important information. Some examples include: Bullet points Bolding Italics Headings and subheadings that break up text ¬† Product-specific genAI outputs included numbered lists and bullet points fairly frequently. But those lists often lacked indentation and appeared exactly like another paragraph of text.¬† Amazon‚Äôs Rufus: The output often included bulleted lists. However, the poor formatting made these bulleted lists hard to scan. Many product-specific genAI features also failed to use bold, italics, and underlining to emphasize key points, forcing users to dig through fluff and unnecessary details to find the information they were looking for. While AI teams might not have control over the outputs generated by an LLM, it is worth exploring options for finetuning outputs and following best practices for web writing.
